title: Cory Booker: A candidate who's 'too nice' may be just what Democrats need to beat Trump
text:
Democrats say they want a return to civility in politics. But can a civil person win against one of the meanest guys in D.C.?

One question predominates among Democratic voters assessing which candidate to nominate as the Democratic standard-bearer for 2020: “Can they beat Donald Trump?”

One person who thus far has not been deemed up to the task by prospective voters is New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker, who has been languishing deep in the second tier of candidates in national polls. So dire was the situation that his campaign put out a memo a little over a week ago warning that if it didn’t raise $1.7 million by Sept. 30, Booker would be forced to drop out of the race. His supporters rallied, and on Monday his campaign announced he had reached its target.

Is there a place for politeness?

Booker has been dogged by concerns that his message of love and togetherness might not be right for the times. The New York Times summed it up in a headline: “Is Cory Booker too nice? (And is that bad?)”

But Booker believes strongly that his approach is the winning way.

In a recent interview, Booker told me that “grace and decency is the way to beat Trump. You can't beat him using his tactics, fighting him on his turf.” Put another way: Never wrestle with a pig. The pig likes it and you get dirty.

Bad news for Biden and Sanders: Democratic activists want youth and diversity

What we need is to have “a revival of civic grace, to have a more courageous empathy, to get back to understanding that we share a common cause and common purpose, and most certainly share a common destiny.” He lamented that Americans are “falling into tribalism in this country where we hate each other so much.”

Sen. Cory Booker, D-N.J., campaigns in Des Moines, Iowa on Sept. 21, 2019. (Photo: Joshua Lott/Getty Images)

On some level, we all know this is true. Yet to many Americans, this kind of talk sounds weak. This is because we have a real misunderstanding about what strength is in politics. There is “this sort of toxic masculinity that is this idea that to be strong, you have to be an ass,” Booker noted. “The antidote to this moment and time is not more Trumpiness. That's why I constantly remind people that love is not weak. Do not confuse strength with meanness. Do not confuse being tough with being cruel. In fact, they are opposites.”

Still, grace for your political enemies feels unnatural, even wrong. It’s a posture that takes a lot of work to achieve. Booker himself admitted on "Late Night with Seth Meyers" in July that he sometimes feels like punching Trump. Many of us know that feeling, so Booker is in no way suggesting that anyone stop hating what Trump is doing to the country. He’s not suggesting we have to be perfect and never utter a bad word about Trump or his allies. He’s just outlining an approach to beating Trump that sounds counterintuitive in the era of clapbacks and cancel culture.

Kindness does not mean never scrutinizing

It also doesn’t mean that Booker can never criticize his Democratic opponents. When Booker pointed out after the last debate that some people were concerned former Vice President Joe Biden might fumble the ball if he became the nominee, many commentators said he was off brand. But that’s because our culture is confused about what grace looks like. Grace does not ask you to be a doormat or have no opinions or never criticize. Loving people does not require you to stay silent when you see something that merits being called out. Certainly, Booker’s concerns about Biden deserved to be heard and considered.

Dem debates don't match the moment: Time to get serious about beating Trump

When I presented Booker with the disturbing math I’ve heard from too many Democrats behind the scenes that it will take a white man to beat Trump, he replied, “This idea that we need a safe candidate that we may not all be excited about, but he's the safe choice, is so contrary to our self-interest.” He added, “And by the way, you make a big mistake if during the campaign the person says something that's racially offensive. That steps in it. And that's why, as a lot of people have written after the last debate, please, Joe Biden, clarify what you were saying about black parents. Please give the guy a chance to clarify because what he said was offensive to black people.”

This pointed criticism is certainly within bounds. A lack of grace involves much more than critiquing an opponent. It looks a lot more like the ad hominem attacks the president launches nearly daily against all who aren’t actively worshiping him. It looks like Trump’s relentless attempts to pit Americans against one another. Trump does this because he cannot survive in an ordered universe free of hatred and chaos, so he works overtime to create disorder. His best hope is that Democrats will sink into the mud with him so that voters will ultimately tune out in disgust, leaving only the most hardened partisans showing up to vote.

Cory Booker gets this. Whether he will break through with his message and vision remains to be seen. But he deserves a real hearing.

Kirsten Powers, a CNN news analyst, is a member of USA TODAY's Board of Contributors and co-host of The Faith Angle podcast. Follow her on Twitter: @KirstenPowers
